markers_reviews.product: Pebeo Acrylic Markers and Sets
markers_reviews.review_title: I would buy again- great fun!
markers_reviews.review_desc: This is my first time trying these markers, and I am thrilled with them. It is such fun experimenting with them. I'm glad they come with an extra nib, since I see the original wearing down. That's not too surprising, given the roughness of the canvases. Will definitely buy again.

markers_reviews.product: Pebeo Acrylic Markers and Sets
markers_reviews.review_desc: Great device, can refill. Runs out of paint quickly

markers_reviews.product: Pebeo Acrylic Markers and Sets
markers_reviews.review_desc: I have about 10 of these markers and they are great. The "ink" is acrylic, so can be used with regular acrylic paint. Applications dry at a reasonable rate and the pen tips do not dry out.

markers_reviews.product: Pebeo Acrylic Markers and Sets
markers_reviews.review_desc: This is absolutely hands down the best Red Acrylic Marker I have ever used. Thank you Pebeo!

markers_reviews.product: Pebeo Acrylic Markers and Sets
markers_reviews.review_desc: Love this pen, perfect for fine lining.

markers_reviews.product: Pebeo Acrylic Markers and Sets

markers_reviews.product: Pebeo Acrylic Markers and Sets
markers_reviews.review_desc: The only acrylic marker I have found that will not bleed when acrylic medium is painted over it. I use these markers for signatures and mark making. Highly recommended if you can't or do not want to spray a fixative over acrylic markers.

markers_reviews.product: Pebeo Acrylic Markers and Sets
markers_reviews.review_desc: I use it for details on acrylic paintings, and for writing on Mixed Media collages. Tis paint goes on smoothly and is mostly transparent.

markers_reviews.product: Pebeo Acrylic Markers and Sets
markers_reviews.review_title: My favorite paint markers - excellent coverage
markers_reviews.review_desc: I use these markers (along with traditional brush and paint) on paintings on wood panels. Love the smooth flow, and the paint can be smudged with fingers or a dry brush for mixing. The replacement nib stored in the cap is also a nice touch. When applying a coat of varnish to finished paintings, I have experienced some paint markers smearing or even dissolving (I assume because they must have contained some form of solvent). These do not smear. I have also not had problems with these drying out or overflowing (have had that with other, professional markers that are more than twice the price). #sweepstakes

markers_reviews.review_title: Handy for transporting into the field.
markers_reviews.review_desc: I just received these Aquash water brushes and the jury is still out. I like their portability for taking outside and appreciate they come in 4 sizes. My daughter (art teacher) loves hers. #sweepstakes

markers_reviews.product: Pentel Aquash Water Brushes and Sets
markers_reviews.review_desc: Firm but flexible brush tip keeps its shape, water reservoir is easy to squeeze. I'm still looking for a water brush that pushes the water directly through the bristles when you squeeze on the reservoir (making it easier to flush out pigment when changing colors), but in the meantime, this brush works well.

markers_reviews.product: Pentel Aquash Water Brushes and Sets
markers_reviews.review_desc: These are some of my favorite water brushes to use for plein air watercolor sketching, and they are especially handy for activating other water-reactive media like water-soluble wax pastels, colored pencils, and inks. They hold a decent amount of water and once you get the hang of how much pressure/flow you prefer, they're very easy to work with. The bristles have superior snap-back quality and offer a lot of control. I love how securely the caps stay on, too. I don't have to worry about jammed or bent hairs when I toss these into a bag or thumbox.

markers_reviews.product: Pentel Aquash Water Brushes and Sets
markers_reviews.review_desc: These are so handy! In some ways they are much better than traditional brushes...I use both, the texture of these adds a very unique option. I almost prefer to just dip then in water...but sometimes the ever-present wet fibers are really handy.

markers_reviews.product: Pentel Aquash Water Brushes and Sets
markers_reviews.review_title: Surprised at how effective these are
markers_reviews.review_desc: This is my first experience with this type of brush and I am finding it helpful for sketching. I saw a YouTube video about these and was surprised that stiff bristles could work but they help to move the paint around. Four stars because I had a little leakage after squeezing one time. Could have been user error.

markers_reviews.product: Pentel Aquash Water Brushes and Sets
markers_reviews.review_desc: They are what I expected. I have used these before

markers_reviews.product: Pentel Aquash Water Brushes and Sets

markers_reviews.review_desc: The large brush is my go-to. I ordered the set because it is economical, but I rarely need the smaller brushes because the large one comes to a nice point and is very versatile.

markers_reviews.product: Pentel Aquash Water Brushes and Sets

markers_reviews.product: Derwent Push Button Waterbrushes and Set
markers_reviews.review_title: Convenient, easy to use, good for loose work
markers_reviews.review_desc: So far I have used these just for water soluble graphite pencil work and they have worked well. I have yet to use the large, chisel brush which certainly would work nicely to cover more ground. Once I figured out how to open and close them (quite easy, just twist off at the top), they are easy to fill and use. I do have small hands so they are a bit bulky and I might not like them if I want to do very fine detail work as I don't feel they offer me control, but, with my small hands, and for looser work, they are great and convenient.

markers_reviews.product: Derwent Push Button Waterbrushes and Set
markers_reviews.review_desc: there are other waterbrushes that I squeeze and squeeze and no water comes out. These work like they are supposed to.

markers_reviews.product: Caran d'Ache Museum Aquarelle Waterbrushes and Set
markers_reviews.review_desc: I purchased the 3-pack of these water brushes. So far, I have not found the felt tipped one very useful. The other 2 with conventional brush tip have been great. Very easy to fill once you get the hang of it. The directions for filling are not clear, however. The squeeze button to release more water is great, and allows you to regulate better the amount of wetness you get. I have used other name-brand water brushes (Kuretake and Pentel) that also worked very well initially. For some reason, all 4 of those brushes started being very difficult to get any water at all to come out of them. I don't know why this would be the case. I only filled them with pure water. In any event, hopefully the Caran d'Aches water brushes will not have this issue. If they hold up, I would give them 5 stars.

markers_reviews.product: Caran d'Ache Museum Aquarelle Waterbrushes and Set
markers_reviews.review_desc: ….With a great price. Perfect for travel.

markers_reviews.review_desc: Nice for travel and quick studies. I find mine leaks unless I really crank it tightly closed (then it works great). Very convenient and mess-free.

markers_reviews.product: Caran d'Ache Museum Aquarelle Waterbrushes and Set
markers_reviews.review_desc: Again I am writing to share that I use the red fibrous tipped brush to hold odorless mineral spirits.. It is double secured because we know that they like to sneak out of the bottle and go everywhere But, using this waterbrush and just adding very little oms I am able to contain the vapors and not have it spill out in my bag. I have used many over the years and just gently touch it to my colored pencil work. It removes the wax glare and shine and loosens up the oil paint inside truly confusing the onlooker. As a watercolorist the inability to let the paint in the pencils get into the crevices off the surface of whether it be hp paper , cp, Pastelmat or sanded paper frustrated me so I 100% recommend this to " keep it contained" and love what one draws.

markers_reviews.product: Artline Poster Markers and Sets
markers_reviews.review_title: Nice markers, but take some prep work
markers_reviews.review_desc: I work for a law firm and bought these markers intending for the lawyers to use them on camera or in front of a jury to mark on darkly printed posters. The markers do indeed leave a nice opaque, very visible paint, but you must shake them and then depress the tips several times to get the paint to flow. This 30 seconds of prep work was too much for our purposes and we ended up just using regular sharpie markers. These markers would still work great on sandwich boards, etc. -- as long as you don't need to mark in front of an audience!

The only thing that you must remember when using them is that the material that you want to apply them to must be non-porous. So if you want to apply it to a drawing on paper, you'll want to apply acrylic or oil paint over the area first, let it dry then apply the liquid chrome to achieve the mirrored affect. They are called, "markers" but, they seem more like a paint pen to me because they have the agitator ball in them like what is found in spray paint cans.

markers_reviews.product: Sakura Pigma Professional Brush Pens and Sets
markers_reviews.review_desc: The ink in these pens is great, the caps fit on the opposite end so it's harder to lose them, and I like the length and shape. The only problem that I have is that the bigger sizes are felt tipped. It's hard to get the amount of line variation in one stroke without rolling the pen onto it's side, and that changes the shape of the line. The medium nib is useless as an in between because the bold tip reaches the same amount of finer lines as it does. The fine nib is by far my favorite despite also being a felt tip. It has the widest range of fine to thick, and if you need to make those lines even thicker it's easy to go over a portion with the bold nib and have it blend smoothly into a thicker line. I'm fairly heavy handed so the fine nib is taking quite the beating and isnt breaking down too quickly. Overall, not bad, but i wouldnt buy them as a set again. i'd just get the fine nib.

markers_reviews.product: Sakura Pigma Professional Brush Pens and Sets
markers_reviews.review_desc: The fine (FB) Sakura Pigma pens are not as sensuously smooth as the slightly less expensive Pigma brush markers, but they are ultimately more of a pleasure to use precisely because of their resistance: you must apply appreciable pressure to get a thicker line, so you can FEEL what line you are producing; they provide haptic feedback. At the lightest pressure, you get close to a 0.5 mm line with a subtle nuance in width. Heavier pressure will go fatter than 1 mm. Gestural marks made with these pens look exquisitely expressive. Do the same with a multiliner and you'll get scribble (these are better for finely controlled hatching); do the same with a Pigma brush marker and you'll get a nice result, but more erratic, less subtle than you can make with the FB pen. If you make lots of thick lines, the Pigma FB pens start losing their juice fairly quickly--but don't throw them out; stored head down they'll regain their flow for a time longer. I'm experimenting with keeping the spent ones till they're fully dry for use in making feathery strokes. As for the price, they're not cheap, but nor are they likely to be cheap to manufacture, and I know of absolutely nothing that can compare with them.

oil_paint_reviews.review_title: I would buy this product again and again.
oil_paint_reviews.review_desc: #sweepstakes. I ordered this color because I was given a sample of it recently from Blick, and I really enjoyed how it enhanced my palette. I used it in painting a Fall scene needing lots of variations of yellows, reds, and oranges in the trees. I often use Alizarin Red, and discovered that Alizarin Orange creates warm, golden yellows and oranges. It is a transparent color, so more of it is required when mixing with opaque colors. It also enhanced the reds I needed, helping them to be more vibrant. I find Williamsburg oils to be high quality.

oil_paint_reviews.review_title: Williamsburg, now my favorite oil paint, deep rich and thick
oil_paint_reviews.review_desc: I am in my third year of oil painting. Since the beginning of the second year I have more and more gravitated to impasto style. I typically use M.Graham and Michael Harding. On a whim I bought this Williamsburg French Earth set. The pallet was perfect for a painting I planned. I love the Williamsburg oil paint... it is very thick, more nearly a paste and consistent across the colors. It is perfect for impasto, but is easily cut with oil to a thinner consistency. This is simply wonderful oil paint. Also, there collections are really fantastic for a consistent look across the color pallet. I have since ordered the Italian... and a set of more contemporary colors.

oil_paint_reviews.product: Williamsburg Handmade Oil Paints and Sets
oil_paint_reviews.review_desc: I've used Williamsburg exclusively to paint portraits. Love the stripe of color on each tube. The material flows and blends well together. Specifically love Pthalo, what a beautiful color to look at.

oil_paint_reviews.review_desc: There are many variations of yellow ochre, some deeper and more saturated and some less so. This particularly rich and high chroma ochre from Michael Harding has recently made its way to my palette. The versatility of this color for landscapes is considerable: painting autumnal foliage, sunrise/sunsets, hay bales, golden fields- I forgot how much I love yellow ochre.

oil_paint_reviews.product: Michael Harding Artists Oil Paints and Sets
oil_paint_reviews.review_title: Alizarin Claret is the new and improved Alizarin Crimson!
oil_paint_reviews.review_desc: Traditional alizarin colors have a mixed reputation when it comes to their lightfastness properties. For this reason, I temporarily quit using it. Unfortunately, I came to miss the vibrant pinks and violets that alizarin crimson lends itself to. Michael Harding's Alizarin Claret uses anthraquinone as its pigment, which is reported to have better resistance to fading. In the image, you will see Michael Harding Alizarin Claret on the right mixed with M. Graham Cobalt Teal (top left) and Rublev Ultramarine Blue (Red Shade) on the bottom left.

oil_paint_reviews.product: Michael Harding Artists Oil Paints and Sets
oil_paint_reviews.review_desc: Michael Harding's Lemon Yellow has recently become part of my palette. As a landscape oil painter, I typically mix the greens that I use rather than using single pigment greens from the tube. In the photo, you will see Michael Harding Lemon Yellow on the right mixed with M. Graham's Cobalt Teal (top left) and Rublev Ultramarine Blue (Red Shade) bottom left.

oil_paint_reviews.review_title: So Nice I Bought Them Twice
oil_paint_reviews.review_desc: I liked the first set of 12 ("Painter's Dozen I") so much that I bought the second. "Painter's Dozen II are softer, more pastel-like colors than the first set (which are generally more bold colors). The consistency of the paints are nice to work with. On velour, colors can be a little blotchy if you overload your brush ("splotches" in water were not intentional in attached five-fish sample). This was me, not the paint, though -- second draft is looking much better. Also on second draft (not shown), colors blend well on velour. Will definitely buy more R+F oil paint sticks in future (especially if I win #sweepstakes prize...)

oil_paint_reviews.review_desc: I really enjoyed this product. It was my first time using oils in a long time, and these were MUCH less messy than tubes. I half expected some difficulty mixing colors, but it wasn't so - at room temperature, was simple to rub onto adjacent spots on palette and then mix with either knife or brush. Pleasant, creamy texture. Thin layer dried quickly enough to paint over in a couple of days without streaking. The only drawback is that the set didn't come with a white oil paint stick -- but that happened to be a Blick bonus at the time I bought, so thanks for that, Blick! Thanks also for the #sweepstakes whereby I might win some $ to buy a few more R+F oil paint sticks.

oil_paint_reviews.product: Holbein Duo Aqua Water Soluble Oil Paints and Sets
oil_paint_reviews.review_title: Love Holbein WSO and highly recommend it!
oil_paint_reviews.review_desc: Just love Holbein Duo WSO and have been using them exclusively for over twenty years. Fabulous, vivid colors! No harmful fumes and the clean-up is with soap and water. When painting, I use regular linseed oil or oil painting medium and the finished painting looks the same as traditional oil paints. I do not dip my brush into water as I'm painting. They dry faster than traditional oil paint on both the canvas and pallet so to keep the paint moist for the next day I simply place Saran Wrap lightly over my pallet and run my finger around each color to create a barrier. Works great! Depending on how thick you apply your paint will determine how tacky or wet your canvas will be the next day.

oil_paint_reviews.product: Holbein Duo Aqua Water Soluble Oil Paints and Sets
oil_paint_reviews.review_desc: I have been using Holbein duo aqua oil for sometime now. I'm in love with the colors. They don't require painting oils or mediums that you would use for normal oil paints so for someone like me who paints in a small space with a kid running around, being able to paint with water without strong smells just made oil painting process more accessible. (Cleaning process is easier too) Initially I tried these out of necessity, but once I tried, I fell in love with their colors and how the colors blend. You can use them with water but they do have their own painting oil too. They are pricy side of paints, however if you like watercolor and wants try oil painting or like watercolor feel paintings, I think they are worth trying.

oil_paint_reviews.product: Daler-Rowney Georgian Oil Paints and Sets
oil_paint_reviews.review_desc: This is the paint I use most, even more than white. It's the opaque, affordable, won't-bleed-through base for monochrome tonal sketches whether they're applied as a wash or as a grisaille, the natural earthy brown of rocks, tree trunks, many shadows, etc. Also great mixed with ivory black to create a good imitation of melanin that is found in most animals (including us). A speck of raw umber takes the saturation down in blues, greens, reds, and violets. Plays very well with ultramarine blue for cool grays. Warning to the new user: it dries darker than it looks when wet, and it keeps on darkening over time, so as soon as it's dry (which occurs quickly), "oil it out" with your favorite medium to get the true depth.

oil_paint_reviews.product: Sennelier Artists' Oil Sticks and Set
oil_paint_reviews.review_desc: I use oil sticks in combination with cold wax oil paints or with encaustics. The oil sticks are used to activate the surface and to add controlled highlights to a work in progress, either by direct application or indirect transfer using a brayer or other tool. The Sennelier oil sticks have a lovely creaminess, cover ground well and dry to a workable stage in an appropriate timeframe. The range of colors in this set is good and covers most needs - a wider range of colors is available as individual crayons. I purchased a set of these oil sticks 15 - 20 years ago, and over time they seemed to disintegrate in that they lost their workability and became a sticky messy headache. The drying time for those oil sticks was weeks to months, which made them impossible to work with. It will be interesting to see how this set behaves over time. Perhaps I need to use them faster! The box they come in is beautiful, but has a huge footprint. That is OK if your workspace has the real estate. I moved mine to a multi-shelf drawer system.

oil_paint_reviews.review_desc: My mother is an oil painter and has been using Grumbacher cadmiums for decades. She is always pleased with them. I recommend a different brand for cobalt violet and I would consider a pale oil version of ultramarine (poppy or safflower) but many of the paints in the Grumbacher line are solid choices for many oil painters. Real cadmium yellow offers better opacity than anything other than bismuth yellow (which is only vivid in its lemon hue, unlike cadmiums which extend into the reds); opacity is generally important in oils.

oil_paint_reviews.product: Richeson Shiva Oilstik Oil Paints and Sets
oil_paint_reviews.review_desc: Shiva Oilstik paint products have been the mainstay of my pallette for decades. Sadly, due to poorly manufactured products, I am put in the position of finding another source of paint stick product. There is a difference in drying times from the older product, there is lack of density in the applied colors, and the hues do not match the older colors. The final dried surface does not resemble the texture nor flatness of the older product. Inconsistency of manufacture is a nail in the coffin of a product that is meant to be in existence forever. The owners of the Shiva product know that the lowering of standards on professional tools will put them out of business, maybe this is what they want, to gut the fine company for a few extra dollars. This a complaint about the entire Shiva line, not any one item, such as Cobalt Blue Hue, which costs the same as Cobalt Blue but is definitely not cobalt blue. This bait and switch is so transparent as to be laughable, what other humdingers are out there?

oil_paint_reviews.product: Winsor & Newton Griffin Alkyds and Set
oil_paint_reviews.review_title: Wish They Came in Larger Tubes
oil_paint_reviews.review_desc: I have been using WN Griffin Alkyds for some time. Although they are not considered professional quality because the pigment load is not the highest, they do tint and cover well, and the paint has good body and spreads consistency. The only thing I don't like is that they come in only 37 ml tubes. But prices are good, so this is a minor inconvenience. They used to come in 70 ml tubes, but they stopped making them for some reason. I would even get them in 120 ml tubes if they were available.

oil_paint_reviews.product: Winsor & Newton Griffin Alkyds and Set
oil_paint_reviews.review_title: Give alkyd oils a try, they may win you over!
oil_paint_reviews.review_desc: If you've never tried alkyd oil paints, you should give them a try. They have a distinctive odor which is a bit unpleasant, but it isn't overwhelming like turpentine. It dissipates quickly. The incredible drying time is the winner for me. The paint is slightly less opaque than traditional oils, but a quick swish in mineral spirits cleans your brushes COMPLETELY with no effort. In virtually every regard, they perform the same as oils, and you can mix your traditional oils into alkyds with no problems (though the drying time will be extended by the traditional oils.) If you like the idea of oil paint that dries within a few hours or almost completely overnight, buy a limited palette of alkyds and go for it. You might switch, particularly if you paint on commission or if drying time is an issue.

oil_paint_reviews.product: Bob Ross Oil Paints and Sets
oil_paint_reviews.review_desc: The Bob Ross Oil Color in Titanium White (6.8 oz) offers great value, especially considering the availability of this size across the full color range. The regular price is already fair for the amount of paint you get, and the sale price makes it an even better deal—8 1/2 times the paint for less than 3 times the cost is fantastic. However, the consistency of this paint is a major drawback. It's impossibly thick—so much so that squeezing it out of the tube requires significant effort. Once out, it takes even more work (and a lot of trial and error) to get it to a usable consistency. Thankfully, I've found that mixing it with Gamblin Solvent-Free Gel helps considerably, making it possible to work it into a smooth, paintable texture. Still, the extra effort is something to keep in mind. If you're willing to put in the time, this paint is a great value for the price, but the consistency may be frustrating for some users. #sweepstakes

oil_paint_reviews.product: Bob Ross Oil Paints and Sets
oil_paint_reviews.review_desc: The Bob Ross Oil Color in Sap Green (6.8 oz) is a fantastic product for anyone using the wet-on-wet technique or painting with oil in general. The availability of all colors in this larger size is a huge plus, as it ensures I can easily stock up on everything I need. Even at regular price, this paint is fairly competitive compared to other professional-grade oil paints. But when it's on sale? It's an unbeatable deal! Getting 8 1/2 times the paint for less than 3 times the cost is an absolute steal and makes this tube an amazing value for serious painters or anyone working on large-scale projects. The quality of the paint itself is excellent—rich pigment, smooth texture, and perfect consistency for the techniques I use. Highly recommend! #sweepstakes

Even at regular price, this paint is fairly competitive compared to other professional-grade oil paints. But when it's on sale? It's an unbeatable deal! Getting 8 1/2 times the paint for less than 3 times the cost is an absolute steal and makes this tube an amazing value for serious painters or anyone working on large-scale projects. oil_paint_reviews.review_desc: Thank you for reaching out! What you're describing is called “oil shed,” and it occurs when pigment settles in the container. The oil actually helps displace air in the tube and is a sign the paint is in good condition. Some pigments, such as titanium, tend to give up oil more readily, and the solution is, as you've found, to simply blot off the excess. oil_paint_reviews.review_desc: Thank you for reaching out! We've checked the batch number you provided and found it as expected. Unfortunately, migration of the oil vehicle to the surface of thickly-applied titanium white is a known phenomenon with titanium pigment, and it does give the appearance of yellowing. Adding an alkyd medium to speed drying can help, as can using an artists' or professional acrylic rather than studio-grade or student as the high pigment concentration will better mask the color of the vehicle. We're happy to keep working with you to find a solution that will meet your needs. Please look for an email from a member of our Customer Care Team who will be in touch to further assist you.

oil_paint_reviews.review_title: My favorite transparent white so far...
oil_paint_reviews.review_desc: This is very light colored, very transparent, and has a nice consistency. Rublev Velazquez medium (calcite in linseed) is the closest commercial alternative but has a sticky consistency, and is yellower (probably because because the Shiva is in safflower). Both sink in less than my own simple mixture of oil and marble dust. I wrote to Shiva and they wrote back quickly, confirming that the pigment is marble dust (W18) and stating that this paint does NOT contain any zinc. So far my test swatches are drying well and not yellowing, but ask me again in a few years...

sketchbooks_reviews.review_title: High Quality Paper - Slightly Rougher than Arches Hot Press
sketchbooks_reviews.review_desc: The book contains high quality hot press paper that is a bit rougher in texture and more absorbent than Arches hot press. The paper has no distracting textural pattern and works well for detailed, small watercolor and pen work, but the high absorbency of the paper makes for a bit of blooming on very fine, small scale line work. The paper doesn't easily pill and allows for smooth washes, layered glazes, and removal of non-staining watercolor mistakes through light scrubbing with a damp brush. Both sides of the paper may be drawn upon in watercolor with no bleed through and there is no real difference in texture between the sides of the sheets. There is a slight bit of buckling with heavier applications of wet in wet watercolor or washes, but nothing extreme. I really wish the cover weren't white and made out of absorbent fabric, but I understand that many people enjoy decorating them. If I had a choice, I'd rather a dark grey, brown, or olive green cover in a leatherette material (like a Moleskine). The cover is a minor complaint though. The book is well made, with a sewn binding, and folds flat for use. Until Arches makes a hot press, hardbound watercolor journal, or Stillman and Birn makes a hardbound book that is 100% cotton (but hot press and extra-heavy like their Zeta paper), this is what I'll buy and recommend to my students when there is a need for a hardbound watercolor book made from 100% cotton hot press paper.

Still, I'd probably buy again but ultimately I think I prefer my Strathmore.

In the past month or so, I have been trying to wake up that long-dormant part of my brain that used to sketch and ink. In the way too many years since high school, my brain has gotten knocked around a bit (tip: do not walk into an open bomb bay door) and working on oil spills did some other types of damage. Result: can't draw a straight or curved line. By doing them over and over and over again, I hope to be able to do them better than I am able to now. So, deciding to use something other than my printer paper or office steno pads, I bought two of the Fabriano 1264 sketch pads, this 9"x12" pad and their 5.5 x8" spiral bound pad. I have only used the 9"x12" so far, using it as my learning and practice pad. I ruled some lines on a couple of pages to make smaller spaces to do pencil and ink learning and sketching. I am also learning to use watercolor paint and pencils, so am taking the opportunity to do a little wet on dry in this book. Despite being 60 lb/80 gsm, the paper held up fine with the painting I did on it as well as a little bit of colored ink and a lot of black ink. The paper feels sturdy enough to not inadvertently rip the perforated pages out. The double-ring spiral binding doesn't snag pages and it is really easy to flip back and forth in the book. My goal is to fill these up and then get more of them. (Don't judge - I've just been doing this for less than a month) #sweepstakes

sketchbooks_reviews.review_title: Good for certain uses, few quality alternatives, pricey
sketchbooks_reviews.review_desc: This is a very good quality sketchbook, but pricey. I have the 10x10, and the cost per page currently is more than 50 cents per sheet. The hard backing is very useful for sketching while sitting or outdoors, and the spiral binding means you can work the full page and lay it flat. Not many similar quality options like this. The ties are a bit of a pain and indent the first and last pages of the book, but I can see they'd be useful for collage or if you are carrying bits of paper within it or tossing it in a backpack and were worried about the corners getting dinked. 4 stars for quality, 2 for relative value, but if money is no object, it's a very nice sketchbook, and will serve certain uses well.

sketchbooks_reviews.review_title: Egalitarian Wonderlust: A Sketchbook for Everyone
sketchbooks_reviews.review_desc: The artPop! sketchbook supports discovery with a rare kind of openness—freedom that feels equal and accessible to everyone. Sometimes, art-making calls for fairness: equal opportunity to explore without hierarchy or privilege, just pure inner indulgence. These sketchbooks are affordable, lightweight, and wonderfully unpretentious. They're a walk in the park. They move with me through the world, protecting good paper in pristine condition until I'm home again. Later, I can tear out a drawing—free and easy—to hang on the wall and see it more clearly. The "easy tear-out pages" are such a high-value feature, and I totally agree with other reviewers on that. Experimenting feels effortless with these. I also love the Stillman & Birn Epsilon series, which satisfies my desire for a thread-bound, indestructible book of 150gsm watercolor-ready pages—a different experience altogether, but equally vital. Beautiful access to both! What fun. To carry them, I use a leather journal cover/folio. I have several, and they'll likely outlast me, solid and timeless. Meanwhile, the drawings on paper remain what they are—spontaneous, free, joyful.

sketchbooks_reviews.review_title: A good product with marketing that missed the mark
sketchbooks_reviews.review_desc: This is a fantastic hybrid of sketch pad and hardcover book. As another reviewer said, this is not what is expected of a sketchbook, where one wants sewn signatures to hold pages in place. For casual sketching, I prefer perfectbound (glued) pads of paper, so that I can remove pages easily. The glossy softcovers of sketch pads leave those pages vulnerable to getting bashed about in my bag. These are glued edge pads of decent quality sketch paper, with a hardcover exterior. If ArtPop! had made this the core of their marketing for this product, or maybe put a sash around the books to keep pages from falling out, they'd probably have happier customers. As it is, the one star review sold me on these! I bought multiple packs. I would not hesitate to give these to artist friends, while explaining the quirk about them. If you love sewn in signatures, Canson makes wonderful hard bound sketchbooks.

We're sorry to hear that these sketchbooks didn't work out for your classroom, and of course we were happy to work with you to make it right. If we can be of assistance in your search for an alternative, please know that our Product Information Team is here to help. Just call 1-800-933-2542 (8am-5:30pm CST M-F) or email info@dickblick.com.
so surprised at how well it holds watercolor
Same quality you expect from their standard notebooks. Nice, bright white, heavyweight paper.

sketchbooks_reviews.review_title: Easy to use, convenient, and overall very lovely
sketchbooks_reviews.review_desc: I got the little, yellow pocket sized sketchbook when it was on sale and I really enjoy it. I was able to fit it easily in my travel art bag. Sketching and painting little things that I want to remember is easy and hassle free. It also isn't an overwhelming size. The page is easy to fill and it looks good after.

I was looking for something (non-spiral bound) that could handle different mediums, as well as take a beating when moving from place to place. So far this sketchbook is, not only my favorite color, but has thick enough pages that it takes quite a bit of product.
I do art and written journals. These journals can put up with lots of "abuse". I have used acrylic paints, watercolors, pastels, collaging.....and the journals hold very well.

I have always wanted a nice and affordable simple sketchbook to draw on using different mediums but could never find one where the paper can take All mediums and not crumple until I found this one! I also love that it come in 3 different sizes!

sketchbooks_reviews.review_title: This is now my go to sketchbook
sketchbooks_reviews.review_desc: I use this for my carry everywhere sketchbbok. It is great for pencil, colored pencil, ink, and marker as long as you do not heavily blend. The paper is pretty heavy weight with a very smooth texture for fine details.
The paper is amazing, and it's the perfect size for me.
This is a beautiful well made book... Attention to detail and quality are so evident!! Thank you so much!!
Great for keeping notes and making sketches

watercolors_reviews.product: M. Graham Artists' Watercolor Tubes and Sets
watercolors_reviews.review_title: M Graham is my favorite brand
watercolors_reviews.review_desc: I paint in a studio in a dry climate, and absolutely nothing is better for that than M Graham. I like how the paints stay soft and are so easy to rewet. The pigment load is the best of all watercolor brands and I like that they focus on single pigments. The earth paints do have a slight odor but I'm a frequent migraine sufferer and the odor causes me no issues, as it's not a chemical smellâ€”it's just the honey mixed with the pigments. I am transitioning my entire palette to M Graham because of the quality. I get really tired of ruining brushes trying to rewet a lot of my Daniel Smith colors that dry hard as a rock in the pan. Those same colors in M Graham are a dream. I get cleaner, less muddy, more transparent washes with M Graham.

watercolors_reviews.product: M. Graham Artists' Watercolor Tubes and Sets
watercolors_reviews.review_desc: After teaching my Watercolor Class I set my newly filled large Steven Quiller Watercolor Palette on top of my van to load all my other class supplies. By the time I remembered and returned it had been run over a few times, there was no saving itâ€¦..ugh! I loved my Quiller Palette! The problem was I had another class coming up and ended to do something. For a long time I had been wanting to switch to a minimal color palette, and this is was my opportunity to give it a try. I quickly ordered my three primary's, on being M. Graham Nickel Azo Yellow. Blick shipped my order quickly, and the creamy honey base that M. Graham puts in their watercolor makes it a great choice for my workshop students. There is less chance that their paints will be all dried out. M. Graham Nickel Azo Yellow is a very clean color. Used thicker and it acts like Quinacridone Gold, a great product for a #sweepstakes review, give it a try, you won't regret it!

watercolors_reviews.product: Crayola Educational Watercolor Pan Sets
watercolors_reviews.review_desc: Purchased these for a watercolor class, and they work very well. The pigment load is solid. They blend well. My students like using the inside of the lid as a palette to mix more specific colors. They may not be the best on the market, but they certainly are worth every penny, especially for beginning artists.

watercolors_reviews.product: Crayola Educational Watercolor Pan Sets
watercolors_reviews.review_title: I would only buy if students were very young
watercolors_reviews.review_desc: The colors activate quickly with water and are quite good. However, comparing it to the slightly more expensive Prang box set, these colors aren't as strongly pigmented. For younger art students, these colors would be totally fine. For older art students, say, over 7 yrs old, I'm staying with Prang semi-moist to help them learn how to mix colors. Prang, also, amazingly, doesn't fade with my test of paint strips in a southern window for a year! I was amazed at that.

watercolors_reviews.product: Crayola Educational Watercolor Pan Sets

watercolors_reviews.product: Brusho Crystal Colours and Sets
watercolors_reviews.review_desc: My 1st time using Brusho, it is fun but I need to play more to incorporate into my watercolors. Lots of colors within this color! #sweepstakes

watercolors_reviews.product: Brusho Crystal Colours and Sets
watercolors_reviews.review_desc: I found that using a thumbtack and poking a hole in the top was much better that taking the whole lid off. Much neater. Spray water on paper, shake colors on, or shake color onto paper, then spray. Bright colors spread in all kinds of patters. You can also sprinkle some onto a palette and add water, then use a brush to paint with. I found this all on YouTube. It would have been nice if this info was in the box with the product. But I do love the many uses, bright colors. Especially nice for creating backgrounds.

watercolors_reviews.product: Brusho Crystal Colours and Sets
watercolors_reviews.review_desc: I have been slowly collecting every color of Colourcraft's Brusho crystals since I first found a couple of jars on the clearance table at my local art supply store. Since then, I have used them for everything from Christmas cards to thank you cards, serious paintings to little sketches and "just for funsies". I experiment and play with them- which is the very essence of what being an artist should be! I have used them on GOOD watercolor paper, to the paper in my sketchbook (which was never meant for watercolor!). They are stunning and versatile- they react differently in different situations. So grab a color & PLAY with it! But WARNING!: You may end up falling in love with them like I did!

watercolors_reviews.product: Brusho Crystal Colours and Sets
watercolors_reviews.review_desc: Brusho is very pigmented and messy. I'm still practicing. I punched a hole in the top with a push pin to control application but I still lose control and it pretty much has a mind of its own.

watercolors_reviews.product: Brusho Crystal Colours and Sets
watercolors_reviews.review_desc: I saw an artist using Brusho to add textures to their watercolor painting- it was very interesting so I decided to purchase a couple of different colors of Brusho- olive green. This is just what I needed to try and I'm still experimenting with diff ways to use the product in my landscapes and I plan on finding other ways to use the product. Love this color and I would purchase it again.

watercolors_reviews.product: Brusho Crystal Colours and Sets
watercolors_reviews.review_desc: This is my first bottle of Brusho and I'm impressed! So many colors show through in this that it makes the area pop! #sweepstakes Note though, the black in here is more to the warm side, closer to Ivory Black than Lamp Black.

watercolors_reviews.product: Brusho Crystal Colours and Sets
watercolors_reviews.review_title: Looking forward to purchasing more Brusho products
watercolors_reviews.review_desc: I used Brusho in a workshop which I enjoyed using the product. I plan to use in backgrounds. #sweepstakes

watercolors_reviews.product: Brusho Crystal Colours and Sets
watercolors_reviews.review_desc: These colors are stunning when applied. They are super concentrated and have a brilliant array of colors come thru even in one color if that makes sense. Because these are super concentrated they do not require a lot to get great color concentration.

watercolors_reviews.product: Brusho Crystal Colours and Sets
watercolors_reviews.review_desc: #sweepstakes This color works great in watercolor landscapers, but be careful because a tiny bit goes a long way.

watercolor_pads_reviews.product: Strathmore 300 Series Spiral Bound Watercolor Pads
watercolor_pads_reviews.review_desc: Great paper for watercolor paintings! It can handle quite a few layers and doesn't curl very much especially if you tape down the edges. BUT I definitely recommend buying the regular pad without the spiral binding if you want to remove your paintings from the pad. The spiral version is great to use as a watercolor sketchbook of sorts, but the pages don't have any perforation, so your only option is to rip or cut them out. The paper is still wonderful, so it's not a huge deal, but it is a little less convenient than the glue-bound pad.

Great practice paper!

watercolor_pads_reviews.review_title: It was even better than expected.
watercolor_pads_reviews.review_desc: I purchased this watercolor paper in order to do 3D art using plaster of paris and watercolor on it. It is perfect. Heavy, decent watercolor paper at a great price.

watercolor_pads_reviews.review_title: Great for daily practice and general purpose
watercolor_pads_reviews.review_desc: I've been using this paper for about a year, trying different things out on it. I bought more because it's well priced for a lot sheets and it works for a variety of media. As far as watercolor goes, it's not high priced cotton, or even high end wood pulp paper. But, it's great for daily painting practice. The attached painting used wet-on-dry, wet-on-wet, lifting, and layering over dry paint multiple times. The paper curled slightly, but not so much that it interfered with painting. I painted it when I figured I had about 45 minutes before I'd be too sleepy to do any art. I would never have started a painting with my good cotton paper in that situation for fear of wasting it. This paper allows me to practice more frequently which in the long run is the most important way of improving my art. For the price and number of sheets, it might be 5 stars.
I use this paper for pencil crayon or graphite drawing.

I bought this to try as an inexpensive general purpose paper – initial composition and testing techniques in watercolor, pencil sketches, thumbnail value studies, art journal, etc. It's great for those uses and so much more. It makes an inexpensive plein air watercolor block if you glue all the sides with tacky glue. Is it like 300 lb cotton? No. Is it still useful for watercolor? Absolutely. You can lift, glaze, use masking fluid, and even do moderate, small areas of wet on wet with just little bit of buckling. It's not for finished watercolor painting, but it lets me get the basics right before attempting a piece on $7 a sheet cotton paper. Beyond watercolor, it works for finished pieces in colored pencil, oil pastel, charcoal, and graphite. But the best part for me is that it can be turned into wonderful sanded pastel paper with just one or two coats of clear gesso (Liquitex or W & N) or Golden pastel ground. Because it's meant for WC, it holds up to the wet application with just slight bending, and dries flat. My pastel painting has improved significantly with this inexpensive option, instead of struggling with pastel papers that have only minimal capacity for layering. I don't have the budget to buy prepared sanded papers, but I do have 10 minutes to turn Vision WC paper into sanded paper. It would be nice to have more options in the pad size, such as 11 x 14, and 12 x 16. Love being able to simplify by using one paper for a wide range of uses. It doesn't replace high end WC paper or specialty papers, such as laid charcoal paper, but it's a versatile, inexpensive paper with good weight. #sweepstakes

watercolor_pads_reviews.review_title: I've used their illustration boards since the 80's.
watercolor_pads_reviews.review_desc: It's pretty sturdy. Not as good as Arches. It seems to want more graphic detail, so I go with the flow.

watercolor_pads_reviews.review_title: Lovely, versatile paper for watercolor and more
watercolor_pads_reviews.review_desc: As watercolor paper, this isn't cotton, and it's not the 400/500 series, so I didn't expect that type of performance. I wanted an inexpensive, decent quality WC pad for use in the field, for practice, and for studies prior to doing a final painting. This is perfect for those uses and exceeded my expectations for the very low price. In the quick study shown, I used wet on wet, lifting, and multiple layers of glazing over dry paint with no problems. I did a masking fluid test and the paper also handled that with no problems. I didn't stretch or even tape the paper down. There was of course some buckling when the paper was saturated, but it dried nice and flat. One downside - this is listed as 140 lb but seems thinner than other S'more 140 lb WC paper. It also has minimal tooth - more like hot press than cold press. On the other hand, its subtle texture makes it wonderful for many drawing media. On the page of doodles, I used wax-based CP, WC pencils, oil-based CP, watercolor and pen, graphite, charcoal, and oil pastel. All these media went on smoothly and easily. As needed, depending on the medium, I blended with stumps, lifted with a kneaded eraser, erased, added multiple layers over existing color, and burnished. Even oil pastel layered easily despite the minimal tooth. I have the Vision Mixed Media pad, and I like this much better for all the media I tested. I also have a variety of other dry media drawing pads. In the future, this will be my primary paper for dry media because it's the most versatile and economical, and performs as well or better than bristol, heavy drawing paper, charcoal paper, etc. I'll also continue to use this as a WC field pad, and for studies and practice. (I made a low-budget plein air block from one pad by gluing the three sides with tacky glue - but leave a gap for a palette knife to remove the sheets!) Almost forgot - both sides are equally usable - the back is a tad smoother than the front.

This paper is only good for ink and pencil. As a watercolor paper, I found it to be poor quality. I've been painting with watercolors for over 35 years, and after using a few sheets of this paper I'm very disappointed. You cannot paint multiple layers on this paper (a must with watercolor) as the paper quickly pills up and the color turns muddy. I wouldn't buy this again. I will use it for drawing with other media, but not for watercolor.
Cold press paper that almost feels like hot press.
Nice set including the paints that are included. Good value.
Paper is really nice! Brush is nice! Schmincke watercolors are always awesome! Price is amazing. It costs more than that just to buy the paint individually!

watercolor_pads_reviews.review_title: I would not buy this again!

We appreciate your business, and your feedback is helpful and always welcome. If we can be of assistance, please don't hesitate to give our Customer Care Team a call at 1-800-723-2787.

I bought a large size pad, and I liked that I could carve up the paintings to appropriate size. The paper does warp a little, and sky washes don't blend quite the way I would like. But price and performance, I'll buy again.

watercolor_pads_reviews.review_title: I will probably buy this again.

watercolor_brushes_reviews.product: Silver Brush Black Velvet Brushes and Sets
watercolor_brushes_reviews.review_title: If you can only buy one brush, buy this one!
watercolor_brushes_reviews.review_desc: I bought these brushes on the recommendation of a watercolor teacher who raved about them. I already own a fair number of brushes both synthetic and natural in a range of quality so I figured these would fit somewhere in the spectrum of what I already owned. I am happy to say I was wrong. These brushes are extraordinary. They soak up a massive amount of water but still remain stiff enough to allow the user a tremendous amount of control. My only negative observation is that they feel funny to the touch - rather coarse. Yes, I know, you're really not supposed to touch your brushes too much, but everyone does it. If I had based my decision to purchase them based on sensory perception rather than third party advice, I would not have bought them. But they are more than worthy of their extraordinary reputation. Buy these brushes!

watercolor_brushes_reviews.review_desc: I bought this for painting miniatures after the Raphael sable brushes were no longer available. It keeps an okay point, but doesn't have much of a belly to hold paint. The brush tip is not very symmetrical and needs to be reshaped often. The quality was better than a few others I've tried, so I am going to try their 0 and 00 to see if it's just the size that's making it difficult.

watercolor_brushes_reviews.product: Blick Master Kolinsky Sable Brushes and Sets
watercolor_brushes_reviews.review_desc: I'm picky about my brushes and I love Blick. Their masterstroke line is better than some of my other French name brand sable brushes. Durable, perfect length, perfectly pliant, and holds water well. If you're a pro I highly recommend this watercolor line.

watercolor_brushes_reviews.product: Blick Master Kolinsky Sable Brushes and Sets

watercolor_brushes_reviews.review_desc: I love these brushes made by Blick. These brushed keep their shape, hold paint, and this size was great for cutting in. I paint detailed and try to be as realist as I can. .These Kolinsky brushed are great for the price.

One must then weigh the options: the superlative sable, or a so so simulacrum. What to do, what to do... Suffice it to say, if you have an extra few dollars in your wallet to spend, it might be worth your while.

watercolor_brushes_reviews.product: Royal & Langnickel Soft Grip White Taklon Brushes and Set
watercolor_brushes_reviews.review_desc: Wow! I purchased the pointed round set that had the small rounds to #6. Mine just have the bottom tipped in blue but they are the same soft grip. I have done nearly everything any watercolorist could do to beat these up. If you are a beginner or professional these are wonderful and I have been doing a tremendous amount of detailing, lifting, scumbling, everything and these really are just as good as the Escoda versátil and frankly hold their points better. I have used from the most expensive to the least and I am truly impressed. They also work great with acrylics. I would love to and have promoted their use even gifting them. I am not finished yet with the composition that I am working on but I would encourage any painter to try these. #Sweepstakes If Royal wants me to promote them I would. You can't beat the price for what they do. Amazing to see a company not cheapen their product and keep boosting their cost.

Have been using one as my primary brush for 2 weeks now and it's point continues to be sharp and frankly as I said, "I'M IN LOVE with it!" It's always a joy to use great artist tools and I'm over the moon being able to share with ladies who have never experienced taking a watercolor class with quality supplies. Am making 'color dot' cards ala Danel Smith color dot cards, for each woman. Of course they will contain Daniel Smith Extra Fine (tm)watercolors!

And I have found that this particular brush can last longer than others I've tried. I am a loyal buyer of this wonderful Angular Shader and would recommend it to anyone who works in small areas that require a lot of detailed work. I have nothing to criticize.

watercolor_brushes_reviews.product: Princeton Summit Series 6850 White Soft Synthetic Brushes and Set
watercolor_brushes_reviews.review_title: I go to Princeton for specialty brushes every time
watercolor_brushes_reviews.review_desc: From the beginning, I have dreaded signing a painting so thanks to Princeton's 003 detail brush the problem is solved. Painting grassy fields in landscapes was also shortened and improved by a new rake brush from Princeton. Those two solutions illustrate why I return to Princeton for specialty brushes that do the job well but at the same time do not cost a small fortune.

watercolor_brushes_reviews.product: Richeson Plein Air Travel Brush Set
watercolor_brushes_reviews.review_title: Could not be happier with my purchase!
watercolor_brushes_reviews.review_desc: I was looking for a good small set of brushes to get back into watercolor. I chose the Plein Air Travel set because I have small hands and prefer a shorter handle. Thes brushes do not disappoint ! The case keeps them from getting damaged . The brushes hold water well and make painting seem effortless. I painted in watercolor years ago. I am now thoroughly enjoying it. I don't think I will need to expand to more brushes either. These do the work needed.

watercolor_brushes_reviews.product: Richeson Plein Air Travel Brush Set
watercolor_brushes_reviews.review_title: Nice brushes and excellent carrier-stand for working outside
watercolor_brushes_reviews.review_desc: I used these for the first time today: Plein Air Watercolor. I like the short handles for working from my car or otherwise away from my art desk. They worked well and just the right size for my outside smallish work.

watercolor_brushes_reviews.product: Richeson Plein Air Travel Brush Set
watercolor_brushes_reviews.review_title: Great set of brushes - Great value
watercolor_brushes_reviews.review_desc: So I was on YouTube feeding my Art Delusion when I learned of the existence of a Pochade Box for Plein Air painting. Woohoo, More equipment! Anyway love these little brushes more than I do the Aqua Elite and Velvet Princeton brushes. I'm slowly putting the perfect kit together at which point I'm certain that I'll be a watercolorin* proficient. 😉

watercolor_brushes_reviews.product: Richeson Plein Air Travel Brush Set
watercolor_brushes_reviews.review_desc: Like the variety of sizes. Easy to take with you.

watercolor_brushes_reviews.product: Richeson Plein Air Travel Brush Set
watercolor_brushes_reviews.review_title: This set has everything needed at a remarkable price
watercolor_brushes_reviews.review_desc: Bought these to take with me on vacations. I have used them in the studio to become acquainted. They appear to hold more pigment than I thought they would. Great fine tip for detail painting. Yes the flats seem small to put in washes on larger paintings, but even then I had no issues on a 12 X 16 painting. And the price just can't be beat. The only thing I recommend is that the manufacturer put a tube over the large flat like the other brushes for shipping. my large flat had bent bristles caused by the strap . To me the price through Blick is unbelievable! So affordable for a great set.

watercolor_brushes_reviews.product: Richeson Plein Air Travel Brush Set
watercolor_brushes_reviews.review_desc: Just perfect, everything you need and really good quality.

watercolor_brushes_reviews.product: Richeson Plein Air Travel Brush Set
watercolor_brushes_reviews.review_desc: Great value for great watercolor brushes! The variety is also wonderful. Love it so much I've purchased a second set for a friend!

watercolor_paper_reviews.review_title: High Quality Paper - Slightly Rougher than Arches Hot Press
watercolor_paper_reviews.review_desc: The book contains high quality hot press paper that is a bit rougher in texture and more absorbent than Arches hot press. The paper has no distracting textural pattern and works well for detailed, small watercolor and pen work, but the high absorbency of the paper makes for a bit of blooming on very fine, small scale line work. The paper doesn't easily pill and allows for smooth washes, layered glazes, and removal of non-staining watercolor mistakes through light scrubbing with a damp brush. Both sides of the paper may be drawn upon in watercolor with no bleed through and there is no real difference in texture between the sides of the sheets. There is a slight bit of buckling with heavier applications of wet in wet watercolor or washes, but nothing extreme. I really wish the cover weren't white and made out of absorbent fabric, but I understand that many people enjoy decorating them. If I had a choice, I'd rather a dark grey, brown, or olive green cover in a leatherette material (like a Moleskine). The cover is a minor complaint though. The book is well made, with a sewn binding, and folds flat for use. Until Arches makes a hot press, hardbound watercolor journal, or Stillman and Birn makes a hardbound book that is 100% cotton (but hot press and extra-heavy like their Zeta paper), this is what I'll buy and recommend to my students when there is a need for a hardbound watercolor book made from 100% cotton hot press paper.

Still, I'd probably buy again but ultimately I think I prefer my Strathmore.

I was gifted the largest watercolor block they make. First removing the paper from the block was so difficult even very carefully using an exact blade that I eventually took all the binding off the block creating individual sheets and losing the benefit of a block which is better than trying to remove a painting and getting a torn painting. The worst problem with this paper (140 lb. Cold press) is that you can not use ANY type of tape or masking fluid on it. The tape lifts the nap and leaves a mark on your finished piece. I tested with this paper, Fabriano, Arches and Blick papers using three different kinds of tape on each paper and none of the papers besides Fluid from Speedball behaved this way. I contacted Speedball, sent them photos and a copy of my husband's receipt and heard nothing back from them. I gave them two stars because other than these two issues it performed fine. These were deal breakers for me to use as watercolor paper, I can use it as collage paper or if I don't plan to mask or tape.

watercolor_paper_reviews.review_title: My GO-TO paper for all things Watercolor.
watercolor_paper_reviews.review_desc: Fabriano 1264 watercolor paper is my go-to paper, of any size. The rougher texture really showcases my granulating watercolors, and even non-granulating colors show more texture. It is also quite affordable, as other brands like Arches and Stonehenge (while worth the money) are out of my league for every day practice.
great deal and price
Highest quality for watercolor painting

This is a fabulous watercolor sketchbook- that is how I use it, filling pages with color notes, scribbles, notes and full on paintings. I have only lately started keeping a painting sketchbook- after 40 some years of painting! I have worked with Fabriano papers before and love the feel of them and their durability. the paper always rises to the occasion to lift my art to best advantage. Looking forward to a year of explorations and fun to fill these many pages. So happy to find it with the Blick site.

Big pad which I can cut up to make smaller sizes.

clay_reviews.review_title: Truly the worst clay I've ever bought
clay_reviews.review_desc: I bought this clay solely because it was one of the cheaper white clays. I've never used talc free clay before, so I'm not sure if they're all like this, but this clay was a disaster. It's so wet that it's sticky and leaves layers of clay when handling it with dry hands, and it has air bubbles and hard clumps of clay all throughout. It's too wet to wedge to help, but I shouldn't have to leave a brand new bag of clay out to dry for me to make it usable. It's truly as if I got a bag of someone's poorly reclaimed clay. I bought 3 boxes of this, so I don't know if the other 2 are like this, but I don't want to find out and will be returning.

I'm a high school art teacher and for the 3rd year in a row, I have purchased this clay for my Ceramics class. It is great clay! Very easy for beginners to work with, easy to recycle, and you can't beat the price! I would recommend this clay to anyone starting out and even to the more advanced artist. The white color when fired allows students to get a true color from the glaze they are using, rather than an altered version. I have had students do everything from coil building, slab, and even throwing with it on the wheel. I'm very impressed with the quality of this product and versatility. You won't be disappointed!

I wasn't sure what clay to buy, so I tried this one because of the price. The clay is very soft and velvety when wet. When you place your newly thrown piece in a bag to dry, the bag scratches the soft wet clay very easily, though you can fix minor imperfections with a sponge later when you trim (as long as you're very careful not to let the edge of the bag dig too deep in the wet clay). When the clay that smudges on the bags dries, it is flaky and gets on your wet clay or drying product, which may or may not be easily wiped away, depending on how wet your product is when you get the dry flakes on it. It feels nice in the hands and works well on the wheel, minus the fact that it creates a ton of slip (I won't have to buy slip because I've been collecting the excess clay from my fingers and palms). I don't want to discourage you from buying this clay because it is something you can work with, but be aware of the challenges listed above. I'm going to shop for a clay better suited to my preferences next time.

Love this clay. It has enough support to handbuild and is still smooth enough to throw on the wheel. The speckles don't develop until cone 5/6 and the color will become more of a rich yellow- tan vs orange so don't let the bisque fool you. In terms of glaze/ clay fit: I had good results with Mayco S & C, Duncan Concepts and most Mayco Fundamental underglazes, except Orange sorbet (UG 85) and pink pink (UG 146) which did eggshell. I also found the Amaco PC colors to be a little muddy on this clay so I now put a coat of white underglaze to help with that. I also suggest mixing Laguna Speckled Buff 50/50 with cone 5/6 B-mix if you want to lighten the color or lower the number speckles.

clay_reviews.review_title: Yes, I will buy this clay again.
clay_reviews.review_desc: This clay initially puzzled me. It felt so different from stoneware, terracotta, etc. It is a porcelain, which is in its white form very different from other clay bodies in that you have to work with it just shy of being too dry. Too wet and it becomes slimy and impossible to control. Once I decided to treat it just like other porcelain, it was not only easy to work with, but quite wonderful. I was impressed with how neat and tidy the process was. Here is a clay that can be worked with in smaller studios, or even at home on a kitchen table! I hand built a sphere using the whole 11 pounds. I will be carving the surface when it reaches the next stage in stiffness. Once it is fired I will share some images.

It air dries solid and after a while, brick hard. Finer/thinner pieces would break if you tried, just like any porcelain or thin piece of wood but it is easy to paint with acrylic paints and seal with clear acrylic enamel.

Note to everyone who picks this up though: This turns everything it touches black while it's still uncured. So wear gloves and cover your surfaces!!

clay_reviews.review_title: I've been through dozens of pounds of this stuff.
clay_reviews.review_desc: I love this stuff. I learned how to sculpt with it and have adapted to it's idiosyncrasies... if you're more experienced with earthen clay or monsterclay you will find it difficult at first. It dries extremely hard and binds permanently to whatever it's stuck to in about 5 hours. I've found that it's best to quickly smooth it on right after mixing, let it harden for about 30-45 minutes, then shape with tools until about the 2.5 hour mark with a barrier of plastic wrap on top to avoid getting the clay on your tools. WEAR GLOVES and whatever you do, don't wash anything or get this stuff anywhere near your sink or drain.

clay_reviews.review_desc: upon first trying this clay, it was easier to work with than ladoll, but it's terrible to finish; if you smooth it with water, it gets soapy and the detail blurs, the water leaves drip marks, and it's hard to paint. buy the ladoll. really. i don't know why every place but blick has stopped carrying the regular ladoll, but it is SO MUCH BETTER than this product. do not be fooled by the "premier" in the title. it is inferior. it is very soft and handles a lot like oil-based clay so is easier to smooth, initially, so if you have no intention of achieving perfection or painting the thing you make, maybe it will work for you. but if you labour over detail, want a smooth surface, and wish to paint it, buy the regular ladoll.

clay_reviews.product: Activa La Doll Satin Smooth Air-Dry Clay
clay_reviews.review_desc: great for small, detailed pieces, light enough for big pieces. just fantastic. very little shrinkage, so can use a substructure for strength and reduce clay usage, works perfectly with acrylic paint.

clay_reviews.product: Activa La Doll Satin Smooth Air-Dry Clay
clay_reviews.review_desc: i use this product to make miniature figures, furniture and food, and life-size busts. it's on the pricey side but well worth it, and blick seems to be the only place that carries it anymore. the ladoll premier is terrible. costs more, so much worse.

clay_reviews.product: Activa La Doll Satin Smooth Air-Dry Clay
clay_reviews.review_title: I have purchased this product again
clay_reviews.review_desc: This product is super easy to work with. Rolls out smooth. Dries fairly quickly without cracks. Cleans up easily. holds paint well.

clay_reviews.product: Activa La Doll Satin Smooth Air-Dry Clay
clay_reviews.review_desc: after trying many, many clays over the years, natural and sculpy and such, this is now the only clay i use. it's lightweight, durable for an air-dry clay, you can sand it and then further smooth it with water, it takes paint well, and there's very little shrinkage. in addition, you can re-hydrate and reuse it. it's great for larger sculptures built on a skeleton, because of it's minimal shrinkage, you can add more clay to it after it's dry without cracking, holds detail and texture so is wonderful for miniatures (i.e. brick or stone). i use it for everything. DON'T buy the ladoll premier, it seems better at first, but if you sand it, you can see the marks. if you wet it, it leaves dimensional drips and you lose the detail in a soapy mess. and it is very hard to paint. Blick on-line is now the only place i know of to get the ladoll clay, for some reason everyplace else has stopped carrying it, but still carries the wretched (and more expensive) ladoll.

clay_reviews.product: Activa La Doll Satin Smooth Air-Dry Clay
clay_reviews.review_title: Best air dry clay I've found so far
clay_reviews.review_desc: Best I've found so far for my purpose.

clay_reviews.product: Activa La Doll Satin Smooth Air-Dry Clay
clay_reviews.review_desc: i don't know why, but every hobby/art supply chain used to carry this clay but now it's gone from everywhere but blick's online store. it is SO much better than ladoll premier, which initially seems to work really smoothly, like the perfect combination of oil based and water based clays, but when you try to smooth it with water after its dry, it runs and pocks and is hard to paint. this less expensive ladoll is far, far superior; the initial workability is a bit harder, but it finishes better and reconstitutes better. it's perfect. i'm dreading that manufacture will cease given that other store's no longer carry it, but still carry the premier. blick charges more than other stores did, but it's the only game left in town, and i hope with all my sculpture-loving heart that they keep selling it, because it's worth it over the premier, at any price. do not be fooled by the premier!

I have used many different 'Air Dry Paper Clays' over the years and have really been pleased with the 'Pearl Paperclay' in my sculpting projects and is reasonably priced. Paints up nice,does sometimes crack in drying process, but this happens with many of the paperclays. Patching is easy, just wet your finger add a pinch of the clay and work into crack. Sands nice, but really I just rub the dried item with a damp cloth and in a hour or 2 is ready to paint.Will continue using this product for my sculpting projects.

I really like this paper clay, the only reason I can't say it is the best in its category is that I have not used every paper clay out there. We made small sculptures out of this in grades 1-12. This stuff is easy to use, easy to attach one piece to another, holds details well, has a smooth finish and dries hard. We added food coloring to some of the clay and made nice marbled colors which was a nice alternative to painting after drying. The biggest drawback on this material is the small size packaging. I would like to see this available in bulk.

I ordered this product and upon arrival it was loose in the large box with other items. Two of the three bottles were leaking. I contacted customer service and after apologizing for the damaged product immediately began the process of completing the return and resending a new order. I contacted customer service and went through the same process. I explained that in the case of the packaging even though the box size was appropriate and there was bubble wrapping it was not around the item and the side of the leaking bottle was on a side without the protection of the bubble wrap. I suggested to tell the packaging employees to actually wrap the item with the bubble wrap and place it in an appropriate size box. My replacement item was well packed as I had suggested and other items I have received have been packaged quite well. I later discovered that the leaking bottles were cracked under the lids. Only issue I have with the clear product even tough it definitely has to be stirred well is that it remains quite thick and I've had to use a considerable amount of liquid clay thinner to get it to a workable consistency but it's still not an ideal consistencybut I will continue to stir, add thinner and use it.

clay_reviews.review_title: An Excellent General Purpose Modelling Material
clay_reviews.review_desc: Back in the late 1990s I was one of the professional sculptors who were consulted by Hope Phillips at Polyform Inc. on this new sculpting material. Many of us in the field had been using regular Super Sculpey for years to create toy prototypes and design maquettes for motion picture special effects, but were dissatisfied with its working properties. Super Sculpey Gray Medium hits the Goldilocks Zone in the world of polymer modelling materials. One of its best qualities is its neutral gray color and opacity, which allows surface finish and details to show clearly before the piece is baked hard. Also, the firmness is just right to hold good detail while having enough flow to capture fleeting gestures. #sweepstakes

Dickblick is where I will always purchase from, since the clay is always fresh straight out of the box!

One thing to note; the warmer the environment and the more you handle it the more malleable it can get. So if you need to work on your piece a lot or create a large item that needs to hold a rigid shape, this may not be the clay for you. I love the fact that I don't have to prep this - you can just open the package and start creating! It also bakes up nicely without the funky toxic-like smell that comes from Fimo. And it comes out as a super light-weight piece. It takes stains and paints beautifully too.

This clay is the best one I've used so far! I've bought more than 30 tubs already and I'm not planning to change brands any time soon. The clay doesn't stick to my hands or tools. Nothing beats FREE shipping as well! Overall satisfied!

clay_reviews.review_title: too hard for small hands to work with
clay_reviews.review_desc: Unfortunately this stuff is just too stiff to work with. Almost impossible for small hands, and unpleasant for anyone.
Great for little hands to model
This was a great goodie bag item for my son's 7th birthday! His friends really enjoyed it and went with the theme of the party.

clay_reviews.review_title: Fantastic learning tool! Love this product in my classroom
clay_reviews.review_desc: Good color selection, easy to use right out of the box without any extra kneading. Holds fine details very well. Color selection also makes it easy to created new hues, Conveniently packaged, easy to distribute and very easy to share. Packaging makes it very easy to control amount to be used and reduce waste. Have purchased both individual Classic set and Classpack. Advantage to the Class pack is the inclusion of neutrals (black, white, brown, grey) further expanding new color possibilities My students have used this modeling clay to create small self-portraits on canvas board and small figures on a wire armature.
My little granddaughter enjoyed this so much,hours of fun!!

clay_reviews.review_title: Where's the white? Sample on package has white!
clay_reviews.review_desc: Used with 5 & 8 year old kids via FaceTime craft time. Great for color wheel and color mixing project. They learned the word tertiary. Introduced them to work of author & illustrator Barbara Reid. They made their own plasticine pictures. Great project. Crayola modeling clay was just right for the age and project, if you don't need white.

clay_reviews.review_title: Great but hard for little hands
clay_reviews.review_desc: Great product overall - what I expected. Only downside is my son is 4 and the clay starts out pretty hard. You have to get it started for them - too hard for little hands.

clay_reviews.review_title: I would buy this product again.
clay_reviews.review_desc: I bought this product for my after school art club. The kids are enjoying how easy it is to work with it and the fact that it doesn't dry out like other modeling clay, so they can use it over and over again.

clay_reviews.review_title: Great for a classroom of primary students
clay_reviews.review_desc: I use this with kinder and 1st grade to do beginning sculpture and to build hand muscles. I love that the colors in the package align with my table colors!

clay_reviews.review_title: This Crayola Modeling Clay is the BEST
clay_reviews.review_desc: We use Crayola Modeling Clay as a part of our Simply Amazing Creative Boxes. Simply Amazing provides art and craft supply boxes to children living in temporary housing, foster care, and participating in youth at-risk programs.This clay is great because it doesn't dry out and the child can use it over and over again.
I was happy to find this modeling clay. It is just what I needed to make "stamps" for use with a gelli plate. Makes cool effects in the prints! #sweepstakes

clay_reviews.review_title: I would buy again and again
clay_reviews.review_desc: My 9 year old granddaughter loves this modeling clay..comfortable to work with and the colours lovely!!

ceramic_reviews.review_desc: Thank you for reaching out! Cosmos Glazes are best suited to vases and sculptural shapes. They do flow during firing and perform best when the inside of the piece is unglazed to allow the necessary off-gassing. We always encourage ceramicists to fire test tiles with their specific application, clay body, kiln environment and firing schedule to determine how to get the best results. If you would like suggestions on how to improve your results, we hope you'll feel welcome to reach out to our Product Information Team. Product Specialists are available weekdays from 8am to 5:30pm CST at 1-800-933-2542 or info@dickblick.com, and they're happy to troubleshoot!

ceramic_reviews.review_desc: Thank you for taking the time to leave a review. We are sorry to hear that your results were not as expected. Please keep in mind that all of the labels for the Speedball Mid-Fire labels are pictures of the glazes fired to Cone 6 on a white stoneware clay. As the opacity of any glaze shifts throughout the surface of a piece, the color of clay often has an effect on the results. We suggest trying it on a white stoneware without speckles to achieve the results you see on the labels. For more information on the characteristics of each glaze, please feel free to reference the Resources Tab on our website.

We're sorry to hear that the Mid-Fire Basque Green glaze did not perform as expected for you. Based on the images you provided, it appears that either the glaze did not quite make it to minimum temperature in the kiln, or the glaze was not applied thick enough. An extended cooling cycle can also affect the results of the Speedball Mid-Fire glazes as well causing some of them to go matte in appearance. Tips for applying and firing this glaze can be found in the Resources Tab on our site. We hope this helps with your troubleshooting and future results, but if we can be of further assistance, please don't hesitate to email info@dickblick.com or call 1-800-933-2542.

Thank you for reaching out! It sounds like you may be firing to Cone 5, because the mottling you're looking for is a Cone 6 result (the clay used for the image is B-Mix). You may want to try using witness cones to make sure your kiln is achieving the correct heat level and avoid slow cooling. Make sure you apply three heavy coats and avoid speckled clays. If your results don't improve, Blick's Product Specialists are available weekdays from 8am to 5:30pm CST at 1-800-933-2542 or info@dickblick.com, and they'll be glad to help!
